The company launched Apps SDK so developers can build actual apps inside ChatGPT instead of just GPTs, meaning you can talk directly to Canva, Zillow, and Coursera without leaving the chat interface. OpenAI also released AgentKit for building agentic workflows with evaluation tools included.

title: NYSE Owner ICE Commits Up to $2B Investment in Betting Platform Polymarket
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-08, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FGPoAFZ/1/01000199c3b90d99-4d7a6d5e-da45-450e-b277-83728dc2ce73-000000/e0DcNx-1YTwN_szwPRi0i-r1N4rsO_Z1Hi09mC90pUE=426
summary: NYSE Owner ICE Commits Up to $2B Investment in Betting Platform Polymarket (3 minute read) The NYSE owner, Intercontinental Exchange (ICE), plans to invest up to $2 billion in the prediction marketplace Polymarket, valuing it at around $8 billion. This move seeks to provide legitimacy and expand Polymarket's reach, potentially aiding its return to the US market. ICE will also distribute Polymarket's event-driven data and collaborate on tokenization projects.

title: Can AI write better?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-08, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.strangeloopcanon.com%2Fp%2Fcan-we-get-an-ai-to-write-better%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/01000199c3b90d99-4d7a6d5e-da45-450e-b277-83728dc2ce73-000000/zuGBUF59qNOkDz3-YYgi7913JGmzbppJSkVAjfMl-Dk=426
summary: Can AI write better? (3 minute read) A founder decided to measure what makes great writing tick, literally. By mapping the rhythm and ‚Äúsurprise spikes‚Äù in authors like Hemingway and Wodehouse, he found each has a quantifiable fingerprint: where sentences get weird, sharp, or musical. He trained a small model to detect those pulses, and it worked. Maybe the next step in AI isn't more scale, but learning how to imitate the texture of human thought.

summary: From Claude Code to Agentic RAG (8 minute read) PageIndex is an LLM-native, vectorless index for PDFs and long-form documents. LlamaFarm allows developers to own their own stack with battle-tested RAG and a friendly CLI.

title: Svelte really is that fast
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-09, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fchuniversiteit.nl%2Fpapers%2Fsvelte-is-fast%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199c8a8aa61-4806c6da-35fd-4a9e-964a-5d2a9b5fcc7a-000000/LXm0W-k8BzoN9G-oobfOev0VYMYjyNCToQ1ko2HCsXo=426

Svelte's performance is due to its reactivity system, optimizing compiler, and binding-based rendering.

title: Seeing like a software company
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-09, Reading time: 18 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.seangoedecke.com%2Fseeing-like-a-software-company%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199c8a8aa61-4806c6da-35fd-4a9e-964a-5d2a9b5fcc7a-000000/ffqCow-rDRBmViIwwhSLExpN82Y9dSl4cBh_HMniNyY=426
summary: Seeing like a software company (18 minute read) Large software companies prioritize legibility (measurability and predictability) over efficiency. While small companies can thrive with illegible, engineer-driven work, large companies require legibility for planning, enterprise deals, and coordination, even if it slows down individual engineers. To balance this, companies create temporary "zones of illegibility" for urgent problems and rely on informal backchannels.

summary: Devs should test their software's installation instructions on a fresh virtual machine. title: Why We Need SIMD
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-09, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fparallelprogrammer.substack.com%2Fp%2Fwhy-we-need-simd-the-real-reason%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199c8a8aa61-4806c6da-35fd-4a9e-964a-5d2a9b5fcc7a-000000/p0nsRlG2YP4HR2ouO_NXTDX4f7VuwSCOZRiY5f-AG1U=426
summary: Why We Need SIMD (The Real Reason) (8 minute read) SIMD (Single Instruction, Multiple Data) instructions give performance gains at a relatively low cost by reusing existing CPU infrastructure. This lets a single instruction perform multiple operations simultaneously. The adoption of SIMD has been hampered by the need for software updates to use new instructions. However, recent advancements are helping increase adoption.

title: The Email They Shouldn't Have Read

summary: The Email They Shouldn't Have Read (8 minute read) This dev helped Agency B and C transition to an open-source mail stack, angering their current provider, who used hidden clauses in their contract to retaliate. The provider potentially spied on their emails and threatened legal action, preventing the agencies from switching and ultimately raising their costs. Despite the ethical issues, the agencies were unable to break free, showing the challenges of escaping vendor lock-in.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-09, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fsyfi.cs.washington.edu%2Fblog%2F2025-10-03-llmc-compression%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/01000199c920b810-e2958e8a-de32-4c7b-b730-7c28c78fa479-000000/EzRkuxcQowBbQVayZx_9QvWiK4PqO4Po73K-WotVhHU=426
summary: Meet LLMc: Beating All Compression with LLMs (4 minute read) LLMc uses AI models to compress natural language. It serves as a high-capacity probabilistic reference system, enabling compression based on token prediction and rank encoding. It efficiently identifies high-likelihood token sequences and encodes them into a compact form using LLMs' in-context capabilities. Benchmarks show that LLMc outperforms traditional compressors such as ZIP and LZMA across a range of datasets.

title: Bitter lessons building AI products
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-10, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fhex.tech%2Fblog%2Fbitter-lessons-building-ai-in-hex-product-management%2F%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/01000199cda59753-8622b292-4000-41fd-aefd-a78bc488e52d-000000/0kgI9D8iHfG5ChmejRXaRWU4cWrxK9Xiu4asG2NSt84=426
summary: Bitter lessons building AI products (9 minute read) You shouldn't try to make AI work for your existing roadmap with fancy, clever engineering because much of it will be obsolete with the next major model upgrade. Instead, aim to understand model capabilities and how you can best pivot your roadmap accordingly. Companies need to learn to kill projects quicker if they need to hack together a solution to make up for intelligence. Just wait a few months and retry the idea when a new model drops.

summary: ksmbd - Exploiting CVE-2025-37947 (7 minute read) CVE-2025-37947 in ksmbd allows out-of-bounds writes due to a flaw in ksmbd_vfs_stream_write() method. By exploiting this vulnerability on Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS, local attackers can achieve privilege escalation by corrupting adjacent kernel pages. However, remote exploitation would require an information leak to bypass KASLR and reliable heap grooming.

summary: Scientists Discovered a New Creature That Exists Between Life and Not-Life (4 minute read) Sukunaarchaeum mirabile is a cellular entity that offloads certain biological functions onto hosts like a virus, but it also contains the necessary genes to create its own ribosomes and messenger RNA. Its discovery highlights the vast unexplored biological novelty within microbial interactions.

summary: Self Actualization (2 minute read) When Andrew Bosworth started Meta's Bootcamp program in 2008, he didn't teach the culture as it was: he taught it as he wished it were. New engineers didn't know the difference. The company grew fast, and within a year, more than half of the engineering team had learned about the culture from him. When onboarding in a high-growth organization, you aren't just teaching people how things work, you're deciding what kind of company they believe they've joined.

title: HTML's Best Kept Secret: The output Tag
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-10-13, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdenodell.com%2Fblog%2Fhtml-best-kept-secret-output-tag%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199dd433eeb-8e2c150a-a9b8-4fa5-afd8-609d2658149b-000000/JdQtaS716UbKNHnfQKJHUyRM2YTkuaQgW3sMKlqjgL0=426
summary: HTML's Best Kept Secret: The output Tag (6 minute read) The often overlooked HTML `output` tag provides built-in assistive technology support for dynamic results. Unlike `div` elements with ARIA attributes, `output` automatically announces its value changes to screen readers. It can be used with or without a `form`, linking to input elements via the `for` attribute, and has great browser support.

summary: Tiny Recursive Models for Very Specific Problems (3 minute read) Samsung just showed you can beat massive LLMs on structured puzzles using a 7 million parameter model trained on only 1,000 examples per task. Its Tiny Recursive Model uses one small 2-layer network that loops over itself, refining both its reasoning state and current answer each pass. It hits 87% on extreme Sudoku, 85% on hard mazes, and 45% on ARC-AGI benchmarks, often beating models thousands of times larger.
